title: Lie algebra
summary: In mathematics, a Lie algebra (pronounced /liː/ LEE) is a vector space g {\displaystyle {\mathfrak {g}}} together with an operation called the Lie bracket, an alternating bilinear map g × g → g {\displaystyle {\mathfrak {g}}\times {\mathfrak {g}}\rightarrow {\mathfrak {g}}} , that satisfies the Jacobi identity. The Lie bracket of two vectors x {\displaystyle x} and y {\displaystyle y} is denoted [ x , y ] {\displaystyle [x,y]} .[lower-alpha 1] The vector space g {\displaystyle {\mathfrak {g}}} together with this operation is a non-associative algebra, meaning that the Lie bracket is not necessarily associative.
